title-group.article-title: Cross-Validation of Mental Health Recovery Measures in a Hong Kong Chinese Sample

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Applied Social Studies, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China
2Department of Social Work, Hong Kong Baptist University, Hong Kong, China

author-notes.corresp: Shengquan Ye, Department of Applied Social Studies, City University of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong, People’s Republic of China. Email: sam.ye@cityu.edu.hk

abstract.p: Objectives: The concept of recovery has begun shifting mental health service delivery from a medical perspective toward a client-centered recovery orientation. This shift is also beginning in Hong Kong, but its development is hampered by a dearth of available measures in Chinese. Method: This article translates two measures of recovery (mental health recovery measure and the recovery subscale of peer outcomes protocol) and one measure of recovery-promoting environments (recovery self-assessment) into Chinese and investigates their psychometric properties among 206 Hong Kong Chinese people with severe mental illness. Result: Multifactor solutions from earlier studies were not replicated; our evidence pointed to one-factor solutions. Since all recovery measures demonstrated high internal consistency reliability (.92 to .96), we analyzed total scale scores. Conclusion: Moderately high correlations among the recovery measures (.33 to .56) provide some support for construct validity, yet further investigation of recovery measures in a Chinese population is needed.

body.p: An accumulation of historical evidence over the past century has begun to moderate the previously bleak prognosis for individuals with severe mental illnesses, particularly for those with schizophrenia (Frese, Knight, & Saks, 2009). Long-term studies of schizophrenia patients have consistently found higher than expected rates of functional (50–59%) and full recovery (22–26%) in follow-up periods of 20 or more years (Bleuler, 1978; Ciompi, 1980; Huber, Gross, Schuttler, & Linz, 1980) suggesting the negative prognosis routinely associated with schizophrenia is frequently incorrect (Hopper, Harrison, Janca, & Sartorius, 2007).

Early in this century in the United States, the President’s New Freedom Commission on Mental Health Report (2002) critiqued a fragmented mental health system based on a disease model that “simply manages symptoms and accepts long-term disability” (p. 1). The Commission posed a challenge to fundamentally transform mental health care in the United States to “ensure that mental health services and supports actively facilitate recovery, and build resilience to face life’s challenges” (p. 1). This shift in the orientation of mental health services from managing long-term disability and toward promoting recovery has resonated in many parts of the Western world (Slade, Amering, & Oades, 2008; Turner-Crowson & Wallcraft, 2002) and has begun taking root in parts of Asia, including Hong Kong (Tse, Siu, & Kan, 2011), Japan (Chiba, Kawakami, & Miyamoto, 2011), and Taiwan (Song & Hsu, 2011). This is a fundamental shift in the paradigm of mental health service delivery from long-term symptom and disability management to a client-centered recovery orientation (Ramon, Healy, & Renouf, 2007).

Promoting recovery has been adopted as either national policy or as the guiding principle of mental health service reform in numerous countries (Siu, Yeung, Poon, & Sun, 2011; Slade et al., 2008). Yet, Slade, Amering, and Oades (2008) describe this growing consensus in policy circles as mere “rhetorical consensus” (p. 128), since there are numerous definitions of recovery and “rationale debate is not possible without conceptual clarity” (p. 128). A fundamental distinction, they argue, is between clinical recovery (also termed recovery as an outcome) which focuses on “sustained remission and restoration of functioning” (p. 128) and personal recovery (or “recovery as a process”) which “focuses on living a satisfying, hopeful and contributing life even with the limitations caused by the illness” (p. 128). These two approaches to defining recovery are different (Andresen, Caputi, & Oades, 2010).

The medical model defines mental illness recovery as absence or remission of a disease (Rudnick, 2008). Yet, from the consumer perspective, recovery does not necessarily mean “cure” (Juvva & Newhill, 2011) in the sense of returning to a preillness state (Ramon et al., 2007). Recovery is also more than symptom management (Bradstreet & Connor, 2005) and may occur without complete symptom relief (Anthony, 1993).

In contrast to the medical model, the developing recovery paradigm adopts a more holistic perspective, incorporating traditional dimensions of symptom reduction, improved functioning, and positive mental health, along with an emphasis on a person’s multiple needs, their empowerment, their involvement in shared decision making, and reintegration into community life (Anthony, 1993; Marshall, Crowe, Oades, Deane, & Kavanagh, 2007; Ramsay et al., 2011; Roe, Joseph, & Midleton, 2010). Liberman and Kopelowictz (2005) described these two approaches to defining recovery as “the process of recovering and recovery as an outcome” that are “in apposition, not opposition” (p. 741).

sec.title: Process Definitions of Mental Health Recovery
sec.p: Many people with severe mental illness can live a satisfying and meaningful life. This has been referred to as recovery (Rodgers, Norell, Roll, & Dyck, 2007), or “personal recovery” (Slade at al., 2008). Bellack (2006) describes consumer definitions of recovery as having emerged “from something akin to a civil rights movement among consumers and a sociopolitical change in public attitudes towards mental illness” (p. 435).

Anthony’s (1993) widely cited process definition defines recovery as “a deeply personal, unique process of changing one’s attitudes, values, feelings and goals, skills, and/or roles … [that] involves the development of new meaning and purpose in one’s life” (p. 15). Similarly, the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration’s (SAMHSA, 2004) National Consensus Statement on Mental Health Recovery identified recovery as a journey of healing and transformation which enables a person with mental illness to live a meaningful life in the community and strive to achieve his/ her full potential. This definition was recently updated by SAMHSA (2012) as “a process of change through which individuals improve their health and wellness, live a self-directed life, and strive to reach their full potential.”

In this sense, recovery includes social recovery and involves building a life beyond illness (South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust and South West London and St George’s Mental Health NHS Trust, 2010). It involves a process of learning how to live with mental illness while striving toward positive goals, including developing a sense of control, self-respect, and an appreciation of life (Smith, 2000). The recovery process reflects changes in experiences (Resnick, Rosenheck, & Lehman, 2004), such as empowerment, hope, potentiality, self-determination, self-efficacy/self-esteem, optimism/control over the future, finding meaning in life, taking responsibility for recovery, reestablishment of identity, and general feeling of well-being/life satisfaction (Andresen, Oades, & Caputi, 2003; Onken, Craig, Ridgway, Ralph,, & Cook, 2007; Resnick, Fontana, Lehman, & Rosenheck, 2005; Rogers, Chamberlin, Ellison, & Crean, 1997). However, as argued by Anthony (1993), the concept of recovery ties these various domains into a single idea. Regardless of the dimensionality of recovery, essential components include hope, meaning, and purpose in life, continual growth, increased control over one’s life, and reestablishment of a sense of self (Loveland, Randall, & Corrigan, 2005).

SAMHSA has promoted the early development of measures of recovery and of recovery-promoting environments through a number of grants for the development of recovery measures in collaboration with mental health consumers. Measuring the Promise: A Compendium of Recovery Measures (Campbell-Orde, Chamberin, Carpenter, & Leff, 2005), contains nine recovery measures and four measures of recovery-promoting environments. It was developed, in part, with SAMHSA support. Song and Hsu (2011) review and critique the reliability and validity of these measures as a stepping off point in the development of their own recovery measure in Taiwan.

sec.title: Nascence of Recovery in Hong Kong
sec.p: The development and implementation of the recovery concept in mental health services is still in its infancy in most Asian countries, including Hong Kong (Tse et al., 2011). Surveys of mental health professionals in Hong Kong have indicated high agreement with the concept of recovery (Siu et al., 2011), albeit with pessimistic attitudes toward the prospect of recovery (Ng, Pearson, Chen, & Law, 2011), as well as a need for more training of professionals in the key aspects of recovery (Mak, Lam, & Yau, 2010). Chiu, Ho, Lo, and Yiu (2010) survey of mental health outpatients found that SAMHSA’s 10 components of recovery (self-direction, individualized and person centered, empowerment, holistic, nonlinear, strength based, peer support, respect, responsibility, and hope) “appeared to contain valid concepts for Chinese subjects” (Chiu, Ho, Lo, & Yiu, 2010, p. 1).

Two measures of recovery have been preliminarily developed in Chinese communities. The Psychosis Recovery Inventory was developed in Hong Kong to measure issues specific to recovery from a first episode of psychosis, including patients’ attitudes toward illness, toward treatment, and their perceptions of personal recovery and risk for relapse (Chen, Tam, Wong, Law, & Chiu, 2005). The Stages of Recovery scale (SRS) was developed in Taiwan (Song & Hsu, 2011) tapping dimensions of recovery very similar to those used by SAMHSA (Chiu et al., 2010). This scale incorporates items derived from several previously developed scales (Campbell-Orde et al., 2005), including the two used in the present study (peer outcomes protocol [POP] and mental health recovery measure [MHRM]). The SRS endeavors to measure both process and outcome dimensions of recovery, and was published at about the time data were collected for the present study.

Qualitative explorations of the concept of recovery in Hong Kong suggest that recovery is multidimensional and includes not only symptom control and medication compliance but also more positive features of regaining previous functions, both cognitive (e.g., being able to concentrate, thinking clearly, and being responsive) and social (e.g., having positive relationships, being respected and respecting others, and independent living; Lam et al., 2011; Ng et al., 2008). These qualitative explorations appear quite consistent with the Western views of recovery from a consumer perspective. Yet, some Chinese investigators wonder whether people with a Chinese cultural mind-set may interpret recovery differently from Western people (Chiu et al., 2010). For example, the emphasis of autonomy and independence in Western society may not be the focus of recovery in the Chinese culture, since “Chinese people’s well-being is significantly determined by a harmonious relationship with others in the social and cultural context” (Hsiao, Klimidis, Minas, & Tan, 2006, p. 998).

Tse, Siu, and Kan (2011) advanced three strategies to help promote the development of recovery-oriented mental health services in Hong Kong, to develop “an understanding of the concepts of recovery in … Chinese communities … [to] grow leaders from within the service user communities. [and to] develop a scale to measure recovery” (p. 3). Reliable and valid measures are essential for evaluating mental health services and assessing the effects of recovery-promoting environments. In this study, we adopt Tse and colleagues’ third strategy, translating and investigating the reliability and validity of two measures of mental health recovery (MHRM; Young & Bullock, 2005; POP—recovery subscale; Campbell, Cook, Jonikas, & Einspahr, 2005) and one measure of recovery-promoting environments (recovery self-assessment; RSA; O’Connell, Tondora, Croog, Evans, & Davidson, 2005a) in a Hong Kong Chinese context.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: A convenience sample (N = 206) of mental health service users at one of the Hong Kong’s largest nongovernmental organizations (NGOs; Baptist Oi Kwan Social Services) was taken during the summer and fall of 2011. This agency provides a spectrum of services which include halfway houses, small group homes, integrated community mental health services, day training centers, and caregiver support services in all areas of Hong Kong (Hong Kong Island, Kowloon, and the New Territories). Study selection criteria included (1) mental health service users of the agency for at least 6 months and (2) no relapse or history of attempted suicide in the past 3 months. Except for a few illiterate participants who were read the questions by staff, the large majority of questionnaires were self-administered. The research project was approved by the agency’s research ethics review board and written consent was received from each participant prior to administering the questionnaire. Completed questionnaires were returned to staff and then given to the research team. All service users who were approached completed the questionnaires. This is not unusual because many were regular service users and Chinese tend to be highly compliant to requests from people with whom they are familiar.

In addition to demographics, the questionnaire contained four standardized measures, the MHRM (Young & Bullock, 2005), the RSA (O’Connell et al., 2005a), the recovery subscale of the POP (Campbell et al., 2005), and the Chinese version of the World Health Organization’s Quality of Life Brief Version (WHOQOL-BREF; Yao, Chung, Yu, & Wang, 2002). With the exception of the WHOQOL-BREF, the other three instruments were translated by the research team. Initial translation by a bilingual research assistant was checked for accuracy by the first and third authors. The research team met and discussed translations with the agency staff to ensure the clarity and applicability of the items to the clients. The questionnaires were then pilot tested with about 20 clients from the agency. Traditional Chinese (as used in Hong Kong and Taiwan) translations of these instruments are attached (Appendices A–C).

sec.title: MHRM
sec.p: Young and Bullock (2005) developed the MHRM to provide a comprehensive evaluation of mental health recovery from a consumer perspective, without measuring psychiatric symptoms. It is a self-report instrument developed from prior qualitative study of the elements of recovery (Young & Ensing, 1999) and contains eight subscales (overcoming stuckness, self-empowerment, learning and self-redefinition, basic functioning, overall well-being, new potentials, advocacy/enrichment, and spirituality; Young & Bullock, 2005). Each item records level of agreement on a 5-point scale, with “1” denoting totally disagree and “5” totally agree. Prior reliability tests have shown good internal consistency (Cronbach’s α of .93 for the total score and .60 to .86 for subscales) and high test–retest reliability (r = .92 1-week, and r = .91 2-week test–retest reliability; Young & Bullock, 2005).

sec.title: POP—recovery subscale
sec.p: Campbell and colleagues (Campbell et al., 2005) developed the POP in collaboration with consumer survivors and their family members “to measure domains that are important to people in recovery themselves” (Campbell-Orde et al., 2005, p. 50). The instrument contains 12 scales and 241 items. This study used only the 13 item Recovery scale (Items 6.25–6.37; Campbell-Orde et al., 2005, p. 185), with each item consisting of a 4-point Likert-type scale with “1” denoting disagree and “4” agree. Internal consistency reliability of the Recovery scale was reported as Cronbach’s α of .86, with a 2-week test–retest correlation of .61 (Campbell-Orde et al., 2005, p. 53). The Recovery scale has also been correlated with Campbell and Schraiber’s (1989) Social Acceptance scale (r = .55) and with Giffort, Schmook, Woody, Vollendorf, and Gervain (1995) Recovery Assessment scale (r = .63) indicating modest preliminary construct validity (Campbell-Orde et al., 2005, p. 53). Within the POP, the Recovery scale was positively correlated with the Personhood scale (r = .88) and the Empowerment scale (r = .79; Campbell-Orde et al., 2005, p. 54).

sec.title: RSA—person in recovery version
sec.p: O’Connell, Tondora, Croog, Evans, and Davidson (2005a) developed the RSA to measure “the degree to which recovery-promoting practices are evident” within a mental health service (Young & Bullock, 2005, p. 91). The RSA has an advantage of multiple versions for different stakeholder groups (person in recovery, service provider, and significant other/family member; Campbell et al., 2005) that allows triangulation of information and comparison across stakeholder perspectives. Only the person in recovery version was used in this study. Agreement with each item is measured on a 5-point scale, with “1” denoting totally disagree and “5” totally agree. Initial assessment of internal consistency reliability of the five RSA subscales (life goals, involvement, diversity of treatment options, choice, and individually tailored services) ranged from .76 to .90, and these subscales jointly accounted for 54% of the scale variance (O’Connell et al., 2005a). A five-factor structure was confirmed in a subsequent study, with internal consistency reliability for the factors ranging from .76 to .89, internal consistency of the total scale at .96, and a 2-week test–retest correlation of .84 (Salyers, Tsai, & Stultz, 2007). This study also provided preliminary indication of convergent (with consumer optimism) and discriminant (hospital vs. community providers) validity using the provider version of the scale. Similar discriminant validity (hospital vs. community providers) was found by Tsai and Salyers (2010).

In relation to predictive validity, the RSA (client, family, and staff versions) has been significantly correlated with “better outcomes in the domains of legal involvement, hospitalization days, education involvement and employment” (Kidd et al., 2011, p. 194). The RSA is one of the four measures of recovery-promoting environments being considered for system-wide implementation in Australia (Burgess, Pirkis, Coombs, & Rosen, 2011). The RSA provider version was also used in a preliminary survey at the largest NGO serving mental health consumers in Hong Kong, with results suggesting low levels of recovery orientation among mental health providers (Mak et al., 2010).

sec.title: WHOQOL assessment
sec.p: The WHOQL Group (WHOQOL Group, 1995) developed the quality of life (QOL) scale consisting of 26 items with four subscales (physical, psychological, social, and environmental), and two individually scored items measuring a person’s overall perception of his QOL and satisfaction with his health. The Chinese version of the WHOQOL-BREF (Yao et al., 2002) was used in this study. Each item is measured on a 5-point scale, with “1” denoting very bad/unsatisfactory to “5” very good/satisfactory. Internal consistency coefficients for the Chinese version ranged from .70 to .77 and the 2-week and 4-week test–retest reliabilities ranged from .76 to .80 for the four subscales (Yao et al., 2002). Yao, Chung, Yu, and Wang (2002) also reported content validity correlations ranging .53–.78 between items/facets and hypothesized domains, criterion related validity correlations between items/facets and overall QOL and general health scores of .32–.78, and significant discrimination “between health and unhealthy subjects on most items/facets and total QOL scores” (Yao et al., 2002, p. 347).

sec.title: Demographics
sec.p: Two hundred and six participants (76 males and 130 females) were recruited, with a mean age of 45.5 years (SD = 11.5, range = 20 to 74). About half were diagnosed with schizophrenia (52%), 24% with depression, 9% with bipolar affective disorder, and 15% with various other illnesses. The mean age at first onset was 28.4 years (SD = 12.4). A large majority received regular medication (91%). The median educational level was senior high school (19% primary school or less, 26% junior high school, 41% senior high school, and 13% college or above). Most were single (64%, 16% married, 16% divorced, and 4% widowed). A minority (30%) held full-time or part-time jobs. The largest religious minority was Christian (44%), followed by those with no religious beliefs (24%), Buddhist (15%), Catholic (6%), ancestor worship (4%), and those with other beliefs (7%).

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics
sec.p: We constructed the scale scores for each measure in accordance with their scoring instructions. Means (SD) for the measures were MHRM 68.8 (20.7); RSA 119.2 (24.4); POP 41.2 (8.1); and QOL 74.5 (13.7). We also calculated the scores for the QOL domains: physical (M = 12.7, SD = 2.67), psychological (M = 11.9, SD = 2.9), social (M = 12.1, SD = 2.9), and environment (M = 12.7, SD = 2.5). QOL domain scores were highly correlated with each other (range of r = .58, .69) and with the QOL total score (range of r = .75, .89). In addition to total scale scores, we calculated scale total scores, standard deviations, and distributional statistics (skewness and kurtosis). See Table 1.

fn.p: Note. MHRM = mental health recovery measure; POP = peer outcomes protocol; QOL = quality of life; RSA = recovery self-assessment.

sec.p: The distributional shape of the MHRM and QOL were quite normal. However, the POP and RSA were significantly negatively skewed and had high kurtosis, suggesting participants tended to provide high ratings on these two scales. We took the square of the original scores of the POP and RSA to normalize the distributions and conducted separate analyses (i.e., t-test, correlation, and analysis of variance [ANOVA]) using the transformed RSA and POP as well as the original data. Results showed no significant differences comparing results derived from the two sets of data (i.e., original and transformed). Therefore, for ease of current understanding and to facilitate future comparisons, we present results derived from analyses using the original data. T-tests found no significant differences by gender on any of the four constructs. Similarly, ANOVA failed to find any significant differences by employment status, and correlation analysis found no significant relationships between recovery measures and education. However, correlation analysis did find age was significantly associated with two of the four measures, having modest positive correlations with POP (r = .25, p < .01), and the RSA (r = .21, p < .01). To test whether this association might be confounded by the experience of coping with illness, we constructed a “years since onset of illness” variable (i.e., current age minus age of first onset) and calculate its correlations with key measures. However, these correlations were all small (range = .06–.08) and nonsignificant, therefore we did not find confounding.

sec.title: Internal Consistency Reliability
sec.p: The internal consistency reliability coefficient (Cronbach’s α) for the QOL total score was .93. Internal consistency reliability coefficients for the MHRM (.96), POP (.92), and the RSA (.96) were also very high. Item level tests were conducted to assess the scale mean and variance if an item was deleted, corrected item-total correlations, and Cronbach’s α if item deleted. Results suggested that the items all performed quite well, with no significant improvements in reliability associated with deleting individual items, in measuring their respective recovery constructs.

sec.title: Factor Structure of the MHRM
sec.p: Factor analyses were conducted to assess the dimensionality of each of the three recovery measures. Common factor analysis (i.e., principal axis factoring), instead of principal component analysis, was adopted because the main purpose of the factor analysis is to identify the underlying structure, rather than extracting fewer uncorrelated components that retain maximum variance (Fabrigar, Wegener, MacCallum, & Strahan, 1999). With oblique promax rotation, the extracted factors are allowed to correlate, which is more consistent with the underlying theoretical relationship among the subscales of the measures.

When considering the number of factors to be extracted, we considered not only the commonly used criteria such as scree test and Kaiser’s rule of eigenvalue greater than 1 but also the more rigorous parallel analysis approach (e.g., Zwick & Velicer, 1986), including the interpretability of solutions. Balancing these various considerations can help avoid a purely data-driven approach to factor extraction. Parallel analysis is a technique that simulates the intended factor analysis using a hypothetical, computer-generated data set and compares resulting eigenvalues with those derived from the studied data. A factor will be extracted when its eigenvalue based on the studied data is larger than the corresponding one resulting from parallel analysis.

We conducted parallel analysis using the program designed by O’Connor (2000), in which the 95th percentile eigenvalues and 1,000 simulated data sets were specified (see Crawford et al., 2010; Longman, Cota, Holden, & Fekken, 1989). Results of factor analysis of the entire MHRM measure suggested that only the first factor (eigenvalue = 14.69; explaining 49.5% of the variance) should be extracted, although the eigenvalues of the three subsequent factors were slightly larger than 1 (i.e., 1.58, 1.20, and 1.13). Factor loadings for the one-factor solution were consistently high, ranging from .54 to .78 (median: .69). Therefore, to avoid the loss of variance that would accompany factor construction, for comparability with other studies, and due to the high internal consistency reliability of the scale (Cronbach’s α = .96), we used the total MHRM score in subsequent analyses.

sec.title: Factor Structure of the RSA
sec.p: We tested the factor structure of the RSA, attempting to replicate the five-factor structure previously reported (O’Connell et al., 2005a, Salyers et al., 2007). While this solution accounted for 62% of the variance, the factor loadings failed to clearly reproduce the original pattern. Parallel analysis (Crawford et al., 2010; Longman et al., 1989) suggested three factors might be extracted, with eigenvalues of 14.1, 2.4, and 1.5 (accounting for 44.1%, 7.5%, and 4.6% of the variance). However, once again the first factor explained the largest amount of variance, with all items loading in the .44 to .88 range (median: .71), and the factor loadings did not occur in the patterns found in previous research. Specifically, items from O’Connell and colleagues’ (2005a) Factors 2 and 3 tended to load on our Factor 1; their Factor 1 and 3 items loaded on our Factor 2. Moreover, in both the three- and five-factor solutions, most items loaded on the first two factors, which were highly correlated with each other (i.e., r = .62 and .58, respectively). Once again, for reasons of parsimony, ease of interpretation, to avoid the loss of variance, and due to the high internal consistency reliability of the whole scale (α = .96), we chose to use the total RSA score in subsequent analyses.

sec.title: Factor Structure of the POP
sec.p: The recovery subscale of the POP was designed for self-assessment of general recovery progress. With the same parallel analysis factor procedure, we obtained a single factor (eigenvalue 6.77, explaining 52.1% of item variance) in the POP scale. Factor loadings were also high, ranging from .54 to .78 (median of .71). This is consistent with the theoretical expectation of the POP recovery subscale as a holistic evaluation of recovery, as no specific domains were differentiated. Therefore, we again used the total scale score (α = .92) in subsequent analyses.

sec.title: Incremental Validity of the Subscales
sec.p: Since factor analysis in the present study did not replicate the multidimensional structure of the MHRM and RSA but in each case suggested a single-factor structure, we investigated how much additional information could be obtained by using original authors’ subscales rather than the total score. The lower section of Table 2 presents the semipartial correlations of each original subscale with the total scale scores of other measures, controlling for the total scale score. This indicates that, for both the MHRM and RSA, when the total score was controlled, the subscales provided very little extra contribution (the semipartial correlations, range = .00–.17, indicating at most a 3% increment in explanatory power) in association with other related constructs.

sec.title: Convergent and Concurrent Validity
sec.p: To investigate convergent and concurrent validity of the measures, correlations among the recovery scale scores were estimated. As shown in Table 2, these correlations were all statistically significant and moderately high (i.e., r = .39, .41, and .54, p < .01). As indicated by the square of the correlations, the recovery measures shared 15–29% of their variance, reflecting meaningful relationships among different aspects of the recovery concept. Moreover, all three recovery measures were significantly correlated with QOL (range = .33–.56, p < .01), suggesting that individuals with higher levels of recovery also enjoyed a higher level of QOL.

sec.title: Discussion and Application to Social Work
sec.p: Findings from this study indicate that the two measures of recovery (MHRM, POP) and one measure of recovery-promoting environments (RSA) that were translated into Chinese and investigated in a sample of Hong Kong mental health consumers all have acceptable psychometric properties. Internal consistency reliabilities were very high, indicating only minimal measurement error. Reliability analysis indicated there were no particularly poor items in the scales. Concurrent validity investigations found moderately positive correlations between the MHRM and the RSA measure of a recovery-promoting environment (r = .39) as well as to the WHO QOL measure (r = .51). Correlations were all consistent with the theoretical expectation of moderate positive relationships in terms of valence, magnitude, and significance.

The significant positive correlation between the MHRM and the POP recovery measures also provides some initial support for their convergent validity. However, the magnitude (r = .54) is a bit lower than might be expected, since these instruments are both designed to measure the concept of personal recovery. At this level, the correlation fails to reach Cavelti, Kvrgic, Beck, Kossowsky, and Vauth’ (2012; relatively high) “critical level of .70 for convergent validity” (p. 24). This can occur for several reasons. Perhaps the scales are not truly measuring the same concepts (i.e., they were developed in different locations, with different groups of consumers, and do not contain the same components of recovery). It is also possible that, since these measures were directly translated from English into Chinese, rather than being developed in Hong Kong, they may not encompass all of the culturally important aspects of recovery for mental health consumers in Hong Kong. In addition, it may be reasonable to expect more variability, and hence less shared variance, when translating an instrument into a different language and applying it cross-culturally.

In relation to the factor structure of the MHRM and RSA, our results did not confirm the multiple-factor structures found in previous investigations. Although both scales were developed to measure multiple domains of recovery, in our investigation, the items and the subscales were significantly correlated and, more importantly, factor analysis tended to suggest only a single factor underlying the scales. Consistent with results from our factor analysis, semipartial correlations indicated there was very little gain in explanatory power that could be derived from using the subscale scores, as opposed to simply using the total scale scores. Therefore, preliminarily, it seems that differentiation of various dimensions in the scales may not be necessary, at least among the Hong Kong sample in the current study.

The present study is one of the first to validate recovery measures among a Chinese sample in Hong Kong. However, several limitations are to be kept in mind in understanding the findings. First, as it is not easy to obtain a representative sample of people with mental illness, our sample was obtained from a local NGO, which is one of the major service providers for mental health care. Although the participants were recruited from different districts in Hong Kong, to what extent they are representative of the total mental health clientele in terms of demographic backgrounds (e.g., educational level, religious belief, age, etc.) is unknown. In addition, most subjects were living in the hostels provided by the NGO. This could give rise to concern for social desirability bias, particularly in assessing the recovery-promoting environment (RSA). However, the mean RSA score in our study is actually a bit lower than that reported by the original authors (O’Connell, Tondora, Croog, Evans, & Davidson, 2005b; 3.73 [.76] vs. 4.06 [.69]), helping alleviate this concern. Many Chinese psychiatric patients tend to be taken care of by their families due to the cultural influences of collectivism and an emphasis on social harmony (Yip, 2004). Differences between clients living in these different environments, as well as the influences of a supervised residential facility compared to a home-living environment are also unknown.

The recent movement in the mental health field toward a recovery-oriented framework has substantial implications for research and practice. Research has begun to develop instruments designed to measure recovery from different perspectives, yet there is still need for greater consensus on the definition and measurement of recovery.

This translation of two recovery instruments and one measure of recovery-promoting environments and investigation of their psychometric properties is intended as a step toward developing reliable, valid, and culturally relevant measures of mental health recovery in the Hong Kong context. Yet, there is also need for theory development and greater cross-cultural sensitivity in the development of recovery measures. An exploratory investigation into whether additional aspects of recovery (from the perspective of Hong Kong mental health consumers) should be incorporated into existing measures seems indicated.

This is important since the definition of recovery may reasonably be expected to vary across cultures. In fact, early roots of the recovery concept can be found in the ancient Chinese text I-Ching (Wilhelm & Baynes, 1977), where the meaning is one of regaining energy and vitality (Tse et al., 2011). Yet, the aspect of energy and vitality does not appear to be directly identified in either the POP or the MHRM. In addition, there may be aspects of recovery in a Chinese society that appropriately reflects the more communal nature of Asian cultures (Song & Hsu, 2011). Cross-cultural investigation of recovery measurement in different cultures can enhance our understanding of both the universal and the culture-specific aspects of the concept.

In practice, the development of recovery measures and measures of recovery-promoting environments is both a step toward and a tool to facilitate the reorientation of the mental health system. We must first measure recovery and recovery-promoting environments before we can investigate whether and to what extent “recovery promoting environments” actually promote recovery. Therefore, the development of culturally relevant, reliable, and valid measures of recovery is an essential prerequisite to promoting a recovery orientation in the mental health system in Hong Kong.
